translated: Sutra on the Four Grades of Learners
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Guá¹‡abhadra of the Song Dynasty
There are three virtues in learning, called true learning, which is the highest grade;
Those who uphold the complete precepts in learning are called followers of the Dharma, which is the middle grade;
Those who receive the lower precepts in learning are called learners who rely on blessings, which is the lowest grade;
Those who practice the three matters are called scattered attendants, which is the outer grade.
Moreover, the three virtues of true learning are:
First, the precepts are fully observed;
Second, one has much knowledge of the scriptures and Dharma;
Third, one is able to transform and liberate others.
These are the three virtues, called true learners.
Moreover, those who uphold the complete precepts purely observe the five precepts, believe in the retribution of good and evil, and follow the teachings of the Dharma.

Those who rely on blessings and the lower precepts only uphold the first four precepts, do not uphold the precept against drinking alcohol, follow worldly customs, and do not change their desires. This is called learning that relies on blessings.
Moreover, the three matters of scattered attendants are not precepts.
What are the three?
First, personally taking refuge in the Dharma;
Second, making offerings to the Dharma;
Third, being known among fellow practitioners.
Those who uphold their own bows, have no teacher, rely on nothing, naturally delight in the mind, and are unconstrained are called those who practice independently.

The merit of true learning surpasses that of relying on the Dharma by a hundred times. The merit of relying on the Dharma surpasses that of relying on blessings by a hundred times. The merit of relying on blessings surpasses that of practicing independently by a hundred times. The merit of practicing independently surpasses that of ordinary people by a hundred times.
Ordinary people may be inferior to animals, while animals may be superior to humans.
Why is this so?
Humans commit offenses, do not stop, enter hell, and after the offenses are exhausted, become hungry ghosts;
After the offenses of hungry ghosts are exhausted, they become animals;ğŸ”½After the offenses of animals are exhausted, they return to being humans.
Animals exhaust all their offenses and then become humans.

Therefore, people should do good, follow the teachings of the Three Jewels, learn the four grades of Dharma, leave the three evil paths for a long time, transmigrate through the heavens, and be reborn in the human realm with great honor. They will receive blessings for generations, and their virtues will increase and lead to liberation.

The Sutra on the Four Grades of Dharma If one loses a single aspect of proper conduct, one should always learn according to the Dharma, respond in a timely manner, and immediately understand the admonitions.
If one is lazy and not diligent, one should be demoted to a lower seat. One can be restored to a higher position later if one has merit;
If one does not heed advice or violates the precepts, one should be expelled and not allowed to join the assembly, lest one corrupt others;
If one has newly received the Dharma and has not yet completed three months, one's transgressions should not be questioned, as one is still inexperienced.
If all learners accept this Vinaya and examine each other from top to bottom, they can then reach the end and quickly fulfill their great vows.
The Dharma of Dispersing Attendance The Dharma of Dispersing Attendance asks:
If there are good men who wish to enter the right path, wish to rely on the great path but cannot endure the precepts, what practices should they do to seek blessings and auspiciousness?
The master said:
There are also three things called the Dharma of scattered attendance, which can be well followed.
What are the three?
First, the Dharma of protecting the body, second, the Dharma of making offerings, and third, the Dharma of fellow practitioners.
Practicing these three things is superior to when one was an ordinary person by a hundred times.
What is meant by the Dharma that the body of a scattered attendant can practice?
Although one does not uphold the precepts, one should be slightly different from ordinary people;

The places one frequents should be places with scriptures and the path. If one sees good deeds practiced by worldly people, the Dharma and evil ones should not be used. Speak good words and recognize them, do not call out ugly words.
This is the first Dharma of a scattered attendant.
What is meant by the Dharma of making offerings of a scattered attendant? How should one attend to the Three Jewels?
Morning and evening, do not be lax, always turn your mind towards it, and cultivate the scriptures together;
If you live in poverty and have no offerings to make, you should increase your diligence and, when you see others' blessings, personally assist them with all your heart.
This is the second Dharma of the scattered attendant.
What, moreover, is the Dharma of the scattered attendant towards fellow practitioners?
You should respect and love them without arrogance. When sitting or rising, think of them, and when entering or leaving, regard them as yourself;
If traveling, when close, ask about each other, and when far, wait and look for each other. Be careful not to be disrespectful.
This is the third Dharma of the scattered attendant.
The master said:

Although the practitioner's three matters have not yet been perfected, they are like the ground with much stone and grass. Although the seeds are not good, they still obtain a little, continuing the time, which is still better than not planting.
Do not neglect planting karma. Eventually, you will obtain good ground, and the seeds will be perfected, with abundant harvest;
This is also so!
If one practices without ceasing, merit and virtue will support one, and one will eventually receive the true precepts.
